T1.label: Cost Leader Resilience
T1.description: Fortescue's sub-US$19/wmt C1 cost position ensures profitability even at iron ore prices of US$85-95/t. Record shipments, operational discipline, and balance sheet strength sustain dividends and cash returns through a downcycle. The stock holds value as a cash flow machine even if iron ore declines moderately.
T1.plain_english: Fortescue's sub-US$19/wmt C1 cost position ensures profitability even at iron ore prices of US$85-95/t. Record shipments, operational discipline, and balance sheet strength sustain dividends and cash returns through a downcycle. The stock holds value as a cash flow machine even if iron ore declines moderately.
T1.what_to_watch: Iron ore price sustains above US$80/t through FY27
T1.upside: Fortescue's sub-US$19/wmt C1 cost position ensures profitability even at iron ore prices of US$85-95/t. Record shipments, operational discipline, and balance sheet strength sustain dividends and cash returns through a downcycle. The stock holds value as a cash flow machine even if iron ore declines moderately.

T2.label: Iron Ore Structural Decline
T2.description: China has passed peak steel production (2020). Property accounts for ~50% of steel demand and is in structural decline. Electric arc furnace (EAF) steelmaking rises to 18% by the 2030s, reducing blast furnace iron ore demand. Simandou delivers 120 Mtpa of high-grade ore by 2030, displacing FMG's lower-grade product. Iron ore falls below US$80/t, compressing FMG earnings by 40%+.
T2.plain_english: China has passed peak steel production (2020). Property accounts for ~50% of steel demand and is in structural decline. Electric arc furnace (EAF) steelmaking rises to 18% by the 2030s, reducing blast furnace iron ore demand. Simandou delivers 120 Mtpa of high-grade ore by 2030, displacing FMG's lower-grade product. Iron ore falls below US$80/t, compressing FMG earnings by 40%+.
T2.what_to_watch: Iron ore price declines below US$80/t
T2.risk_plain: China has passed peak steel production (2020). Property accounts for ~50% of steel demand and is in structural decline. Electric arc furnace (EAF) steelmaking rises to 18% by the 2030s, reducing blast furnace iron ore demand. Simandou delivers 120 Mtpa of high-grade ore by 2030, displacing FMG's lower-grade product. Iron ore falls below US$80/t, compressing FMG earnings by 40%+.

T3.label: Green Energy Pivot Succeeds
T3.description: Fortescue Energy delivers a viable green business: green iron metal technology achieves commercial scale, hydrogen partnerships (TES) succeed, and copper exploration (Alta in Peru) provides diversification. The Energy division transitions from a capital sink to a profit contributor.
T3.plain_english: Fortescue Energy delivers a viable green business: green iron metal technology achieves commercial scale, hydrogen partnerships (TES) succeed, and copper exploration (Alta in Peru) provides diversification. The Energy division transitions from a capital sink to a profit contributor.
T3.upside: Fortescue Energy delivers a viable green business: green iron metal technology achieves commercial scale, hydrogen partnerships (TES) succeed, and copper exploration (Alta in Peru) provides diversification. The Energy division transitions from a capital sink to a profit contributor.

T4.label: Forrest Governance & Capital Misallocation
T4.description: Andrew Forrest's ~36% shareholding and Executive Chairman role enables capital misallocation without effective board oversight. Green energy investments destroy shareholder value as Forrest pursues a personal legacy project. The "founder trap" prevents the company from optimising capital allocation for minority shareholders.
T4.plain_english: Andrew Forrest's ~36% shareholding and Executive Chairman role enables capital misallocation without effective board oversight. Green energy investments destroy shareholder value as Forrest pursues a personal legacy project. The "founder trap" prevents the company from optimising capital allocation for minority shareholders.
T4.risk_plain: Andrew Forrest's ~36% shareholding and Executive Chairman role enables capital misallocation without effective board oversight. Green energy investments destroy shareholder value as Forrest pursues a personal legacy project. The "founder trap" prevents the company from optimising capital allocation for minority shareholders.

presentation.heroDescription: Iron Ore • 198 Mt Shipped (FY25) • US$7.9B EBITDA
presentation.heroCompanyDescription: Fortescue Ltd (ASX: FMG) is the world's fourth-largest iron ore producer, supplying approximately 10% of global seaborne iron ore. Founded by Andrew Forrest in 2003, Fortescue shipped a record 198.4 Mt in FY25 from its Pilbara operations at an industry-leading C1 cost of US$18.17/wmt. The company also operates Fortescue Energy, pursuing green hydrogen, green iron, and copper opportunities.

skew.rationale: Iron ore faces structural decline from China peak steel, Simandou adds 120 Mtpa of new supply by 2030, green energy writeoffs have destroyed capital, and the stock trades well above consensus broker targets. Forrest governance adds capital misallocation risk.

verdict.text: Fortescue's Metals division is a world-class mining operation: record 198.4 Mt shipped at US$18.17/wmt C1 cost, generating 56% EBITDA margins. But the investment case is overwhelmed by structural headwinds. China has passed peak steel (2020), iron ore prices are forecast to decline to US$83-95/t by end-2026, Simandou will add 120 Mtpa of new supply, and the Energy division has written off US$150M+ on cancelled green hydrogen projects. Andrew Forrest's ~36% stake concentrates governance risk. The stock trades above consensus broker targets of A$18.58-19.86, making it one of the few ASX 50 stocks where the market is more bullish than analysts.

presentation.featuredRationale: World-class iron ore cost position, but China peak steel, Simandou supply, green writeoffs, and Forrest governance risk. Stock above broker consensus targets.

identity.overview: World's fourth-largest iron ore producer, supplying approximately 10% of global seaborne iron ore from Pilbara operations in Western Australia. FY25 record shipments of 198.4 Mt at an industry-leading C1 cost of US$18.17/wmt (hematite). Two operating divisions: Fortescue Metals (iron ore, 56% EBITDA margin) and Fortescue Energy (green hydrogen, green iron, copper). Energy division has scaled back significantly: cancelled Arizona hydrogen and PEM50 projects with US$150M+ in writedowns. Green hydrogen cost of US$4.50-6.00/kg remains uncompetitive versus grey hydrogen at US$1.00-2.00/kg. Continuing energy initiatives include green iron metal technology, TES partnership, and copper exploration (Alta deal in Peru). Founded by Andrew Forrest, who remains Executive Chairman with ~36% shareholding.

hypotheses.title: T1: Cost Leader Resilience
hypotheses.description: Fortescue's sub-US$19/wmt C1 cost position ensures profitability even at iron ore prices of US$85-95/t. Record shipments, operational discipline, and balance sheet strength sustain dividends and cash returns through a downcycle. The stock holds value as a cash flow machine even if iron ore declines moderately.
requires: Iron ore price sustains above US$80/t through FY27
Dividend payout maintained at 50-65% of NPAT
supporting: Filings: Record 198.4 Mt shipped at US$18.17/wmt C1 cost. EBITDA margin 56% (Metals)
Competitor: FMG is the lowest-cost major after Rio Tinto. Cost position is structural, not cyclical
Economic: Iron ore at ~US$100/t still generates US$80+/t margin for FMG
Filings: Balance sheet strong: US$4.3B cash, 0.27x D/E, manageable capex cycle
Academic: Low-cost producers survive commodity downturns; high-cost exits first
contradicting: Economic: Iron ore price consensus is US$83-95/t by end-2026, compressing margins
Competitor: Simandou adds 120 Mtpa of high-grade supply, potentially displacing FMG's lower-grade ore
Broker: Stock trades above consensus targets, suggesting cost leadership is fully priced

hypotheses.title: T2: Iron Ore Structural Decline
hypotheses.description: China has passed peak steel production (2020). Property accounts for ~50% of steel demand and is in structural decline. Electric arc furnace (EAF) steelmaking rises to 18% by the 2030s, reducing blast furnace iron ore demand. Simandou delivers 120 Mtpa of high-grade ore by 2030, displacing FMG's lower-grade product. Iron ore falls below US$80/t, compressing FMG earnings by 40%+.
requires: Iron ore price declines below US$80/t
Simandou achieves first commercial shipments (Jan 2026 announced)
FMG grade discount widens as Simandou high-grade enters market
supporting: Economic: China passed peak steel in 2020. Property (~50% of steel demand) in structural decline
Competitor: Simandou first shipments January 2026. 120 Mtpa at full capacity by 2030
Economic: EAF steelmaking rising to 18% by 2030s, reducing blast furnace demand
Broker: Iron ore price forecasts converge at US$83-95/t by end-2026, declining further beyond
Academic: China's steel intensity per capita has peaked; development model shifting to services
contradicting: India's urbanisation could partially offset China's decline over the medium term
Simandou ramp-up may be delayed (infrastructure complexity in Guinea)
China's steel decline is gradual (5-7 Mt/year), not precipitous

hypotheses.title: T3: Green Energy Pivot Succeeds
hypotheses.description: Fortescue Energy delivers a viable green business: green iron metal technology achieves commercial scale, hydrogen partnerships (TES) succeed, and copper exploration (Alta in Peru) provides diversification. The Energy division transitions from a capital sink to a profit contributor.
supporting: Corporate: Green iron metal technology is potentially differentiated (direct reduction with green hydrogen)
Corporate: TES partnership provides access to European energy storage markets
Corporate: Alta copper acquisition in Peru provides commodity diversification
contradicting: Filings: Energy EBITDA loss of US$700M in FY25. Arizona and PEM50 cancelled. US$150M+ writedowns
Economic: Green hydrogen at US$4.50-6.00/kg is 3-6x more expensive than grey hydrogen at US$1.00-2.00/kg
Filings: Capex of US$3.9B includes significant Energy spend with no return
Academic: Green hydrogen cost parity projected for 2030s at earliest
Broker: No analyst models Energy as a positive NPV contributor within 5 years

hypotheses.title: T4: Forrest Governance & Capital Misallocation
hypotheses.description: Andrew Forrest's ~36% shareholding and Executive Chairman role enables capital misallocation without effective board oversight. Green energy investments destroy shareholder value as Forrest pursues a personal legacy project. The "founder trap" prevents the company from optimising capital allocation for minority shareholders.
supporting: Filings: US$150M+ writedowns on cancelled green projects. Energy EBITDA loss US$700M
Governance: Forrest as Executive Chairman with ~36% stake creates unchecked capital allocation power
Academic: Founder entrenchment correlates with value-destructive diversification in ~60% of cases
Media: Persistent coverage of Forrest's green ambitions as personal crusade vs shareholder value
contradicting: Forrest built FMG from nothing into a US$68B company; track record of value creation is extraordinary
Energy division scale-back shows willingness to cut losses (Arizona, PEM50 cancelled)
Metals division capex discipline has been maintained; operational management is world-class

narrative.theNarrative: The market narrative is a contest between "world-class iron ore cash machine" and "structural decline with governance risk." Fortescue Metals is undeniably excellent: record shipments, industry-leading costs, and a fortress balance sheet. But the stock trades at A$20.10, well above broker consensus of A$18.58-19.86, suggesting the market is pricing in either iron ore price resilience or green energy optionality that analysts do not see. The structural headwinds are formidable: China has passed peak steel, Simandou is about to add 120 Mtpa of high-grade ore, and the Energy division has destroyed hundreds of millions in capital with nothing to show for it.

priceImplication.label: Embedded Assumptions at A$20.10
priceImplication.content: Iron ore above US$100/t sustained: Current price requires iron ore to hold near current levels, which contradicts consensus forecasts of US$83-95/t. Cost leadership sufficient: Market assumes sub-US$19/wmt costs protect earnings even in a downturn. Energy pivot optionality: Some premium for green iron and copper exploration. Dividend sustained: 4.95% yield at 65% payout assumes NPAT does not decline further. China soft landing: Market pricing gradual steel decline, not a sharp correction.

narrative.evidenceCheck: The evidence is sharply divided by segment. Metals is strong: record shipments, lowest-quartile costs, strong balance sheet, and disciplined operations. Energy is a capital sink: US$700M EBITDA loss, US$150M in writedowns, no path to profitability within 5 years. The macro evidence is uniformly negative for iron ore: China peak steel, Simandou supply, EAF growth. The operational evidence is uniformly positive for the Metals division. These two forces are in direct tension, and the stock price suggests the market is weighting Metals resilience more heavily than structural decline.
narrative.narrativeStability: Unstable, skewed negative. The narrative will be shaped by iron ore price trajectory and Simandou ramp-up timing. Each quarter of iron ore price decline weakens T1 and strengthens T2. The Energy division narrative has already shifted from "bold green pivot" to "capital destruction" following project cancellations. If iron ore breaks below US$90/t, the stock will likely re-rate toward consensus targets of ~A$19.

evidence.intro: Ten evidence domains assessed. Evidence is bifurcated: Metals division operational metrics are excellent, but structural macro headwinds and Energy division losses create a clear downside skew when combined with a stock price above consensus targets.

cards.title: 1. Corporate Communications
cards.finding: Management framing FY25 as a "record year" for iron ore shipments (198.4 Mt). CEO Dino Otranto emphasising Metals operational excellence and cost discipline. Energy narrative has shifted from transformational ambition to "disciplined capital allocation" following Arizona and PEM50 cancellations. FY26 shipment guidance of 195-205 Mt suggests confidence in Metals. Green iron metal positioned as the next Energy priority, replacing hydrogen. New CEO of Energy (Gus Pichot, from July 2025) signals strategic reset.
cards.tension: The pivot in Energy messaging from "green hydrogen will transform the world" to "disciplined capital allocation" is a significant narrative reversal. Management is reframing capital destruction as strategic flexibility. The Metals messaging is credible and supported by independently verifiable operational data.
cards.source: FMG FY25 Results; Investor Day presentations; ASX announcements; CEO commentary

cards.title: 2. Regulatory Filings & Financial Statements
cards.finding: FY25 (audited): Revenue US$15.5B (-15%), EBITDA US$7.9B (51% group margin, 56% Metals). NPAT US$3.4B (-41%). FCF US$2.6B. Capex US$3.9B (including significant Energy spend). Cash US$4.3B, net debt US$1.1B, D/E 0.27x. Metals segment: 198.4 Mt shipped (record), C1 cost US$18.17/wmt (hematite). Energy segment: EBITDA loss US$700M. Writedowns on Arizona hydrogen (US$85M) and PEM50 (US$66M). Dividend: A$1.10/share, 65% payout ratio. Revenue decline driven entirely by lower iron ore prices, not volume.
cards.tension: The financial statements reveal a company with two fundamentally different businesses under one roof. Metals is a world-class cash generator; Energy is burning cash at scale. The group EBITDA margin of 51% masks Metals at 56% and Energy at deeply negative. The question for investors is whether they are buying a mining company or subsidising a green energy experiment.
cards.source: FMG FY25 Annual Report; Half-year accounts; ASX filings; segment disclosures

cards.title: 3. Broker Research
cards.finding: Consensus is cautious. Of analysts covering FMG: 2 Buy, 7-9 Hold, 2 Sell. Average 12-month price target A$18.58-19.86, implying 6-12% downside from current price. This is unusual: FMG is one of the few ASX 50 stocks where the market price sits above broker consensus. Broker iron ore price decks centre on US$90-100/t for 2026, declining to US$83-95/t by end-2026 and further beyond. No analyst models Energy as a positive NPV contributor within 5 years. Bulls focus on dividend yield and cost position; bears focus on iron ore price trajectory and Simandou.
cards.tension: When the stock trades above analyst targets, either: (a) analysts are behind the curve on a positive catalyst the market sees; or (b) the market has overshot and will revert. For FMG, option (b) appears more likely given the uniformly negative iron ore price trajectory in consensus forecasts.
cards.source: UBS, Macquarie, Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, Citi consensus data; iron ore price decks

cards.title: 4. Competitor & Industry Data
cards.finding: Simandou is the transformational event. First shipments from Guinea announced for January 2026, with full capacity of 120 Mtpa targeted by 2030. This is the largest new iron ore supply source in decades and will add high-grade ore (65% Fe) that directly competes with and potentially displaces FMG's lower-grade product (58-60% Fe). Competitive positioning: Rio Tinto and BHP have lower or comparable C1 costs; FMG's advantage is scale and Pilbara infrastructure. Vale and the Simandou consortium (Rio Tinto, Winning Consortium) will add supply that the market does not need. FMG's grade discount could widen as high-grade supply increases.
cards.source: Rio Tinto Simandou updates; BHP, Vale filings; industry capacity surveys; Fe grade analysis

cards.title: 5. Economic Data
cards.finding: China's steel demand is in structural decline. Peak steel was reached in 2020 at approximately 1.065 billion tonnes. Property construction accounts for ~50% of steel demand and is contracting. New housing starts have declined significantly since 2021. Demand declining 5-7 Mt/year. EAF (electric arc furnace) steelmaking is rising from ~15% to a projected 18% by the 2030s, reducing blast furnace (and therefore iron ore) demand. India's urbanisation provides partial offset, but Indian steelmakers increasingly source domestic ore. Iron ore consensus forecast: US$83-95/t by end-2026, declining further as Simandou ramps.
cards.source: National Bureau of Statistics (China); World Steel Association; IEA; Mysteel; commodity forecasts

cards.title: 6. Alternative Data
cards.finding: China property data is the leading indicator. Real-time property transaction data, cement production, and excavator utilisation rates all confirm the structural decline in Chinese construction activity. Satellite imagery of Pilbara port activity confirms record FY25 shipments. Employee sentiment (Glassdoor) is mixed: Metals workforce satisfied; Energy division employees report uncertainty following project cancellations and restructuring. Andrew Forrest's public advocacy for green energy continues at a pace disconnected from the company's Energy division retreat.
cards.source: Satellite port data; China property transaction data; Glassdoor; Forrest public statements

cards.title: 7. Academic Research
cards.finding: Commodity supercycle research supports the structural decline thesis. Published research on China's steel intensity curve shows it has followed the pattern of Japan and South Korea: rapid industrial build-out, peak steel, then secular decline as the economy shifts to services. Green hydrogen cost research confirms that cost parity with grey hydrogen (US$1.00-2.00/kg) is not achievable before the mid-2030s at current technology trajectories. Low-cost commodity producer research confirms that cost leadership provides resilience in downturns: the lowest-quartile producers survive and gain market share as high-cost producers exit.
cards.source: Commodity cycle research; China steel intensity studies; green hydrogen cost analysis; low-cost producer literature

cards.title: 8. Media & Social
cards.finding: Coverage dominated by Forrest personality and green energy narrative. Andrew Forrest's public profile drives disproportionate media attention. Coverage bifurcated: mining press focuses on iron ore fundamentals and Simandou; general media focuses on Forrest's green hydrogen advocacy and climate commitments. Financial media increasingly sceptical of Energy division following project cancellations. Retail investor sentiment on forums is divided: yield investors hold for the dividend; growth investors question capital allocation.
cards.source: Australian Financial Review; mining press; financial media; retail investor forums

cards.title: 9. Leadership & Governance
cards.finding: Founder dominance is the central governance question. Andrew Forrest holds ~36% of FMG and serves as Executive Chairman, giving him uncontestable control over capital allocation, strategy, and board composition. His track record is extraordinary: he built FMG from a concept into a US$68B company. But the Energy division's US$700M EBITDA loss, US$150M in writedowns, and the cancellation of flagship projects (Arizona, PEM50) demonstrate the risks of founder-directed capital allocation without effective board constraint. CEO Dino Otranto (Metals, expanded role from Aug 2023) is highly regarded for operational excellence but operates within Forrest's strategic framework. Gus Pichot (Energy, from Jul 2025) represents a strategic reset of the Energy division. Key employees: ~15,642, predominantly in Pilbara mining operations.
cards.tension: Tension: Forrest simultaneously created extraordinary shareholder value (building FMG) and destroyed it (Energy division losses). The same attributes that enabled the former (conviction, risk appetite, personal capital commitment) enable the latter.

rows: Founded FMG; Minderoo Foundation; Australia's largest individual shareholder
Former Fortescue COO; mining operations specialist
Energy sector executive; strategic reset mandate

cards.source: FMG Annual Report; ASX announcements; board composition disclosures; Minderoo Foundation

cards.title: 10. Ownership & Capital Flows
cards.finding: Forrest's 36% stake dominates the register and the investment case. Andrew Forrest's holding makes FMG effectively a founder-controlled company despite its ASX 20 size. His stake is worth approximately A$24B, making him Australia's largest individual shareholder. Institutional ownership is typical for an ASX 20 miner: passive index funds, global resource funds, and yield-seeking investors. Short interest is modest (~2-3%), reflecting that most bearish investors simply underweight rather than short a high-yielding, liquid miner. The register is stable but lacks the "smart money" accumulation that would signal a re-rating catalyst. Key dynamic: Forrest's stake means the company cannot be acquired, merged, or subjected to activist pressure, which removes a source of capital discipline present in other large miners.
cards.source: ASX substantial holder notices; ASIC disclosures; annual report top-20; index fund filings

discriminators.intro: Three data points carry high diagnosticity. Iron ore price is the single most important variable. Simandou ramp-up timing determines the supply outlook. Energy division capital allocation determines governance risk.

rows.evidence: Iron ore price trajectory through 2026. Sustained above US$100/t supports T1; decline below US$90/t activates T2.
rows.discriminatesBetween: T1 (cost leader resilience) vs T2 (structural decline)

rows.evidence: Simandou ramp-up milestones. First commercial shipments and ramp-up pace toward 120 Mtpa.
rows.discriminatesBetween: T2 (supply shock real) vs T2 delayed (infrastructure delays)

rows.evidence: Energy division capex allocation in FY26. Continued spend vs further cuts.
rows.discriminatesBetween: T4 (capital misallocation continues) vs T4 mitigated (Forrest showing discipline)

rows.evidence: China property starts trajectory. Stabilisation vs continued decline.
rows.discriminatesBetween: T1 (demand floor holds) vs T2 (demand accelerates downward)

discriminators.nonDiscriminating: "FMG has a low P/E" (commodity stocks always have low P/Es near cycle peaks) • "Dividend yield is attractive" (yield depends on iron ore price, which is the question) • "Green energy is the future" (true, but FMG's green hydrogen is uncompetitive at US$4.50-6.00/kg) • "Forrest is a visionary" (personality is not evidence; capital allocation outcomes are)

tripwires.intro: Three revision conditions. Iron ore price is the dominant variable. Each US$10/t decline in iron ore removes approximately US$2B from FMG's annual revenue.

cards.name: Iron Ore Price Trajectory

conditions.if: If iron ore sustains above US$100/t through 2026
conditions.then: T1 (Cost Leader) strengthens. Margins hold. Dividend sustained. Stock may re-rate slightly.

conditions.if: If iron ore declines below US$85/t for ≥3 months
conditions.then: T2 (Structural Decline) confirmed. Earnings compress 30%+. Dividend at risk. Stock re-rates toward A$15-17.

cards.source: Source: Platts IODEX; SGX iron ore futures; major bank commodity forecasts

cards.name: Simandou Ramp-Up

conditions.if: If Simandou ramp-up is delayed beyond 2027 for infrastructure reasons
conditions.then: T2 timeline extends. Supply overhang deferred. FMG has more time to deliver returns.

conditions.if: If Simandou achieves ≥50 Mtpa by end-2027
conditions.then: T2 accelerates. High-grade supply pressures FMG's grade discount. Market oversupply confirmed.

cards.source: Source: Rio Tinto/Winning Consortium updates; Guinea government announcements; shipping data

cards.name: Energy Division Capital Allocation

conditions.if: If Energy capex <US$500M and focused on near-commercial projects
conditions.then: T4 (Governance Risk) mitigated. Forrest showing capital discipline. Energy division right-sizing.

conditions.if: If new large-scale green hydrogen commitments announced without commercial pathway
conditions.then: T4 strengthens. Capital misallocation continues. Minority shareholders subsidising Forrest's green ambitions.

cards.source: Source: FMG FY26 results; ASX capex guidance; Energy division disclosures

couldntAssess: Simandou ramp-up reliability: Guinea's political stability, infrastructure readiness, and consortium execution are uncertain. A significant delay could materially change the T2 timeline.
FMG grade discount trajectory: As Simandou adds high-grade (65% Fe) supply, FMG's lower-grade ore (58-60% Fe) may face a widening quality discount. The magnitude of this effect is uncertain.

Energy division forward commitments: The extent of remaining Energy division commitments, contractual obligations from cancelled projects, and Forrest's personal willingness to continue funding green initiatives is unclear.
India demand offset: Whether India's steel demand growth can materially offset China's decline is an open question with wide uncertainty bands.
gaps.analyticalLimitations: Hypothesis survival scores (T1: 30%, T2: 30%, T3: 15%, T4: 26%) reflect editorial assessment. The equal weighting of T1 and T2 is deliberate: both are supported by strong evidence from different domains. T1 (Cost Leader) is supported by operational data; T2 (Structural Decline) is supported by macro data. The question is timeline: T1 may hold for 2-3 years while T2 plays out over 5-10 years. T3 (Green Pivot) is scored lowest because the evidence uniformly contradicts it following project cancellations and hydrogen cost gaps. T4 (Governance) is rising because each green writeoff provides additional evidence of capital misallocation.

crossover.description: 50-day MA crossed above 200-day MA during structural uptrend

trend.structure: Higher lows from April 2025 trough; structural uptrend with recent pullback

support.method: Round number and recent pullback low (Feb 2026)

priorSpikes.context: Selloff to A$14.20; iron ore price weakness
Breakout above A$19; iron ore recovery

inflectionPoints.event: Pullback from highs; testing 50-day MA support

footer.disclaimer: This report does not constitute personal financial advice. Continuum Intelligence synthesises cross-domain evidence using the Analysis of Competing Hypotheses (ACH) methodology. All factual claims are sourced from ASX filings, company accounts, broker consensus data, and publicly available information. This report does not contain buy, sell, or hold recommendations, price targets, or valuation models.

big_picture: Fortescue Ltd (ASX: FMG) is the world's fourth-largest iron ore producer, supplying approximately 10% of global seaborne iron ore. Founded by Andrew Forrest in 2003, Fortescue shipped a record 198.4 Mt in FY25 from its Pilbara operations at an industry-leading C1 cost of US$18.17/wmt. The company also operates Fortescue Energy, pursuing green hydrogen, green iron, and copper opportunities.

last_flip.trigger: Automated: survival score shift (Cost Leader Resilience  Iron Ore Structural Decline)
